sp.p: I must doe it; there is no remedie. I must cut off your legs, sirrha, I must cut off your eares, you rascall, I must doe it; I must cut off your nose, I must cut off your head.

sp.speaker: BRAY.
sp.p: O, good your worship.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: Well, rise, how doest thou doe, now? doest thou feele thy selfe well? hast thou no harme?

sp.speaker: BRAY.
sp.p: No, I thanke your good worship, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: Why, so! I said, I must cut off thy legs, and I must cut off thy armes, and I must cut off thy head; but, I did not doe it: so, you said, you must serue this gentleman, with my warrant, but, you did not serue him. You knaue, you slaue, you rogue, doe you say you must? sirrha, away with him, to the iayle, Ile teach you a trick, for your must, sir.

sp.speaker: BRAY.
sp.p: Good, sir, I beseech you, be good to me.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: Tell him he shall to the iayle, away with him, I say.

sp.speaker: BRAY.
sp.p: Nay, sir, if you will commit mee, it shall bee for committing more then this: I will not loose, by my trauaile, any graine of my fame certaine.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: How is this!

sp.speaker: KNO.
sp.p: My man, BRAYNE-WORME!

sp.speaker: STEP.
sp.p: O yes, vncle. BRAYNE-WORME ha's beene with my cossen EDWARD, and I, all this day.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: I told you all, there was some deuice!

sp.speaker: BRAY.
sp.p: Nay, excellent Iustice, since I haue laid my selfe thus open to you; now, stand strong for mee: both with your sword, and your ballance.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: Bodie o'me, a merry knaue! Giue me a bowle of sack: If hee belong to you, master KNO'WELL, I bespeake your patience.

sp.speaker: BRAY.
sp.p: That is it, I haue most need of. Sir, if you'll pardon me, only; I'll glorie in all the rest, of my exploits.

sp.speaker: KNO.
sp.p: Sir, you know, I loue not to haue my fauours come hard, from me. You haue your pardon: though I suspect you shrewdly for being of counsell with my sonne, against me.

sp.speaker: BRAY.
sp.p: Yes, faith, I haue, sir; though you retain'd me doubly this morning, for your selfe: first, as BRAYNE-WORME; after, as FITZ-SWORD. I was your reform'd souldier, sir. 'Twas I sent you to COBS, vpon the errand, without end.

sp.speaker: KNO.
sp.p: Is it possible! or that thou should'st disguise thy language so, as I should not know thee?

sp.speaker: BRAY.
sp.p: O, sir, this ha's beene the day of my metamorphosis! It is not that shape alone that I haue runne through, to day. I brought this gentleman, master KITELY, a message too, in the forme of master Iustices man, here, to draw him out o' the way, as well as your worship: while master WELL-BRED might make a conueiance of mistris BRIDGET, to my yong master.

sp.speaker: KITE.
sp.p: How! my sister stolne away?

sp.speaker: KNO.
sp.p: My sonne is not married, I hope!

sp.speaker: BRAY.
sp.p: Faith, sir, they are both as sure as loue, a priest, and three thousand pound (which is her portion) can make 'hem: and by this time are readie to bespeake their wedding supper at the wind-mill, except some friend, here, preuent 'hem, and inuite 'hem home.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: Marie, that will I (I thanke thee, for putting me in mind on't.) Sirrah, goe you, and fetch 'hem hither, vpon my warrant. Neithers friends haue cause to be sorrie, if I know the yong couple, aright. Here, I drinke to thee, for thy good newes. But, I pray thee, what hast thou done with my man FORMALL.

sp.speaker: BRAY.
sp.p: Faith, sir, after some ceremonie past, as making him drunke, first with storie, and then with wine (but all in kindnesse) and stripping him to his shirt: I left him in that coole vaine, departed, sold your worships warrant to these two, pawn'd his liuerie for that varlets gowne, to serue it in; and thus haue brought my selfe, by my actiuitie, to your worships consideration.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p:
And I will consider thee, in another cup of sack. Here's to thee, which hauing drunke of, this is my sentence. Pledge me. Thou hast done,
or assisted to nothing, in my iudgement, but deserues to bee pardon'd for the wit o' the offence. If thy master, or anie man, here, be angrie with thee, I shall suspect his ingine, while I know him for't. How now? what noise is that!

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.p: Sir, it is ROGER is come home.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: Bring him in, bring him in. What! drunke in armes, against me? Your reason, your reason for this.
I Beseech your worship to pardon me; I happen'd into ill companie by chance, that cast me into a sleepe, and stript me of all my clothes—

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: Well, tell him, I am Iustice CLEMENT, and doe pardon him: but, what is this to your armour! what may that signifie?

sp.speaker: FORM.
sp.p: And 't please you, sir, it hung vp 'i the roome, where I was stript; and I borrow'd it of one o' the drawers, to come home in, because I was loth, to doe penance through the street, i' my shirt.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: Well, stand by a while. Who be these? O, the yong companie, welcome, welcome. Gi' you ioy. Nay, mistris BRIDGET, blush not; you are not so fresh a bride, but the newes of it is come hither afore you. Master Bridegroome, I ha' made your peace, giue mee your hand: so will I for all the rest, ere you forsake my roofe.

div.head: Act V. Scene V.
div.stage: ED. KNO'WEL, To them. WEL-BRED, BRIDGET.

sp.p: WE are the more bound to your humanitie, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: Only these two, haue so little of man in 'hem, they are no part of my care.

sp.speaker: WELL.
sp.p: Yes, sir, let mee pray you for this gentleman, hee belongs, to my sister, the bride.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: In what place, sir?

sp.speaker: WELL.
sp.p: Of her delight, sir, below the staires, and in publike: her poet, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p:
A poet? I will challenge him my selfe, presently, at extempore.
Mount vp thy Phlegon muse, and testifie,
How SATVRNE, sitting in an ebon cloud,
Disrob'd his podex white as iuorie,
And, through the welkin, thundred all aloud.

sp.speaker: WELL.
sp.p: Hee is not for extempore, sir. Hee is all for the pocket-muse, please you command a sight of it.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: Yes, yes, search him for a tast of his veine.

sp.speaker: WELL.
sp.p: You must not denie the Queenes Iustice, Sir, vnder a writ o' rebellion.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p:
What! all this verse? Bodie o' me, he carries a whole realme, a common-wealth of paper, in's hose! let's see some of his subiects!
Vnto the boundlesse Ocean of thy face,
Runnes this poore riuer chang'd with streames of eyes. How? this is stolne!

sp.speaker: E. KN.
sp.p: A Parodie! a parodie! with a kind of miraculous gift, to make it absurder then it was.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: Is all the rest, of this batch? Being me a torch; lay it together, and giue fire. Clense the aire. He was enough to haue infected, the whole citie, if it had not beene taken in time! See, see, how our Poets glorie shines! brighter, and brighter! still it increases! Ô, now, it's at the highest: and, now, it declines as fast. You may see. Sic transit gloria mundi.

sp.speaker: KNO.
sp.p: There's an embleme for you, sonne, and your studies!

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: Nay, no speech, or act of mine be drawne against such as professe it worthily. They are not borne euerie yeere, as an Alderman. There goes more to the making of a good Poet, then a Sheriffe, Mr. KITELY. You looke vpon me! though, I liue i' the citie here, amongst you, I will doe more reuerence, to him, when I meet him, then I will to the Major, out of his yeere. But, these paper-pedlers! these inke-dablers! They cannot expect reprehension, or reproch. They haue it with the fact.

sp.speaker: E. KN.
sp.p: Sir, you haue sau'd me the labour of a defence.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: It shall be discourse for supper; betweene your father and me, if he dare vnder-take me. But, to dispatch away these, you signe o' the Souldier, and picture o' the Poet (but, both so false, I will not ha' you hang'd out at my dore till midnight) while we are at supper, you two shal penitently fast it out in my court, without; and, if you will, you may pray there, that we may be so merrie within, as to forgiue, or forget you, when we come out. Here's a third, because, we tender your safetie, shall watch you, he is prouided for the purpose. Looke to your change, sir.

sp.speaker: STEP
sp.p: And what shall I doe?

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: O! I had lost a sheepe, an he had not bleated! Why, sir, you shall giue Mr. DOWNE-RIGHT his cloke: and I will intreat him to take it. A trencher, and a napkin, you shall haue, i' the buttrie, and keepe COB, and his wife companie, here; whom, I will intreat first to bee reconcil'd: and you to endeuour with your wit, to keepe 'hem so.

sp.speaker: Step
sp.p: Ile doe my best.

sp.speaker: COB.
sp.p: Why, now I see thou art honest, TIB, I receiue thee as my deare, and mortall wife, againe.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: And, I you, as my louing, and obedient husband.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p:
Good complement! It will bee their bridale night too. They
are married anew. Come, I coniure the rest, to put of all discontent. You, Mr. DOWNE-RIGHT, your anger; you, master KNO'WELL, your cares; master KITELY, and his wife, their iealousie.
sp.l: For, I must tell you both, while that is fed,
Hornes i' the mind are worse then o' the head.

sp.speaker: KITE.
sp.p:
Sir, thus they goe from me, kisse me, sweet heart.
See, what a droue of hornes flye, in the ayre,
Wing'd with my densed, and my credulous breath!
Watch 'hem, suspicious eyes, watch, where they fall.
See, see! on hends, that thinke th'haue none at all!
O, what a plenteous world of this, will come!
When ayre raynes hornes, all may be sure of same. I ha' learn'd so much verse out of a iealous mans part, in a play.

sp.speaker: CLEM.
sp.p: 'Tis well, 'tis well! This night wee'll dedicate to friendship, loue, and laughter. Master bride-groome, take your bride, and leade: euery one, a fellow. Here is my mistris. BRAYME-WORME! to whom all my addresses of courtship shall haue their reference. Whose aduentures, this day, when our grand-children shall heare to be made a fable, I doubt not, but it shall find both spectators, and applause.

div.p: This Comoedie was first Acted, in the yeere 1598.
By the then L. CHAMBERLAYNE his Seruants.
With the allowance of the Master of REVELLS.
